Unbalanced piece of shit

Recently released on Steam just a day ago, people are currently review bombing Overwatch 2. Some are for more valid reasons, some for less. After all, this game has an incredibly complex and nuanced history. 

Many are rightfully angry about development promises that did not come to fruition, others dislike the monetization changes that occurred during Overwatch's switch to a free to play game. Some reviewers are simply bitter about the state of the Team Fortress franchise, and take it out by review bombing similar games. 

Regardless of this game's current "overwhelmingly negative" rating, I highly encourage anybody reading this to play Overwatch. Between 38 playable characters and 26 maps of varying game modes, every game of Overwatch feels entirely unique. This is helped by the fact that these characters, or "heroes" follow little standardization. Individual heroes have anywhere from 3 to 7 abilities. One hero uses a sniper rifle that heals teammates; another carries a giant swinging hammer. There's even a hero that is a giant mechanical bowling ball piloted by a super-intelligent hamster. 

All of this is to say that Overwatch is one of the most unique and engaging games I have ever played. Whether I'm playing a high production open world game or a simpler indie game, I always find myself coming back to Overwatch afterwards.

Many of the people currently reviewing this game have a right to be angry. But Overwatch is an amazing game that makes me feel a way no other game does. If you have any interest in playing, I highly recommend that you do so.

[b]Overwatch 2 has seemingly deviated from its prior deference to players, adopting a veneer of continuity from its predecessor while effectively pursuing pecuniary gain.[/b]

In the year 2016, I initially engaged with the game and, akin to numerous others, promptly became enamored by its allure. Overwatch continued to occupy a prominent position among my preferred shooters throughout subsequent years, even during the period marked by a paucity of content leading to the advent of OW2.

While the title retains its endearing design, captivating ensemble of characters, and commendable multiplayer maps, Overwatch 2 has introduced notable deviations that cast a pall over its foundational essence. Permit me to elucidate:

[i]#1 - Restriction of Heroes within the Sphere of the Battlepass Framework[/i]

Foremost among these alterations is the confinement of heroes within the parameters of the Battlepass framework, an alteration of profound significance.

Overwatch is grounded in the selection of heroes and the orchestration of team dynamics. Each distinct character confers unique advantages, with varying degrees of compatibility or incongruity. In its previous iteration, Overwatch periodically introduced new heroes to its player base, fostering an inclusive environment devoid of financial barriers. However, Overwatch 2 now demands either a protracted commitment to the acquisition of new heroes or pecuniary expenditure via the Battlepass to gain access upon release (or a fee of £9 for established heroes).

Though superficially innocuous, this transformation bears consequence as players can partake in competitive gameplay with an incomplete hero roster.

This presents a crucial facet of gameplay sequestered behind a monetary threshold, a construct that runs counter to principles of competitive parity.

How can equitable competition persist when one cohort of players possesses a plethora of options solely due to financial disbursement? The semblance to a "pay-to-win" model is discernible, though I defer to your discretion in formulating this judgment.

[i]#2 - The Battlepass Framework and the Evolution of Cosmetic Aesthetics[/i]

My disposition toward the concept of the Battlepass framework has heretofore been one of tempered concurrence; however, when juxtaposed with analogous implementations in other gaming contexts, OW2's iteration is decidedly wanting. Each iteration of the Battlepass proffers an assemblage of 80 tiers of rewards, conventionally encompassing 8 distinct skins (augmented by an admirably customizable variant as the culmination), alongside sundry ancillary accoutrements, as is the norm. This latter category encompasses designations, insignias, and gestures. It warrants mention that a recent addition includes "credits," a commendable augmentation, yet one that falls short of rectifying the foundational error of entrenching pivotal gameplay attributes behind a monetary barrier.

The role of cosmetics within Overwatch has historically been of pivotal import, epitomized by the creations of accomplished artists and modelers responsible for crafting superlative skins. The aesthetic merit of these offerings endures, yet their valuation is characterized by audacity. Notably, legendary skins, denoting designs beyond mere chromatic reconfigurations, approximate an average price point of £20 or more per unit.

Heretofore, these cosmetic items were obtainable through the mechanism of lootboxes, awarded with each advancement in player level, a frequency that could be deemed appreciable. In my personal trajectory within the game, my engagement with direct box purchases was intermittent, yet I managed to amass a substantial collection of skins spanning various characters. The rationale often cited in defense of the transition to a commercial model was predicated on the notion that the extant munificence of the lootbox system was compromising fiscal viability, an assertion I find subject to dispute. Evidently, by the year 2019, a mere triennium post-launch, Overwatch had amassed a cumulative revenue of $1 billion through the medium of lootboxes.

Presently, avenues for acquiring cosmetic embellishments devoid of fiscal exchange are notably restricted, unless one is inclined to endure protracted trials to secure a singular legendary skin over a span of months.

[i]#3 - The Praxis of PvE Implementation[/i]

While my personal inclination seldom gravitated toward Player versus Environment (PvE) experiences, it is imperative to note that this facet was heralded as a focal pillar underpinning the narrative of Overwatch 2's proposition.

In principle, that was the prevailing tenor; however, the eventual manifestation transpired as a bait-and-switch maneuver, ostensibly orchestrated to facilitate the integration of novel monetization mechanisms. Curiously, even in the wake of the ostensibly delineated cessation of PvE endeavors, discrete PvE missions persist, albeit available as individualized acquisitions, serving as yet another conduit to extract monetary remuneration.

[i]In Conclusive Recapitulation[/i]

For devotees of competitive shooters, Overwatch 2 appears to be wanting in its adherence to the principles undergirding competitive integrity.

For adherents of the cosmetic acquisition facet, Overwatch 2 necessitates a financial commitment of significant magnitude.

While the factor of amusement remains extant, thereby retaining vestiges of the gratifying experience that once resonated, its essence is overshadowed by the intrusion of acquisitive proclivities to an extent that compels me to withhold endorsement for discerning enthusiasts.

Is anyone surprised about the bad reviews? this is the first time people have been able to voice their disappointment of how Overwatch 2 came out.  This game is fun, i enjoy playing with friends, but this is not overwatch 2. This is Overwatch 0.1... They took out alot of features from the first game and started adding some back. The matchmaking is terrible, if either feels like your washing through the enemy or getting washed by the other side. It never feels even. I'm a silver player and found out i was fighting diamonds in casual. One shot characters are terrible for this game. it forces you to constantly hide behind walls instead of attacking the point. and the only counters are one shot characters, or completely switching out the tank. The worst part is the absolutely atrocious report system. Blizzard relies on the community to report people and never look at the reports. Someone has to get mass reported to get banned. The cheaters dont give a crap. they get banned and just make a new account. Ive been called the N word and racist remarks and only once got the banned notification. This game is full of potential but has a terrible company behind it. The only thing carrying this game is the art team and sadly the Porn creators.

Overwatch 2 is the epitome of Blizzard failure. 

Adding this game to Steam is nothing more than a pathetic attempt to recoup years of failure.
This game is full of broken promises, such as the pve mod. The esport scene is dying, and the game designers refuse to learn from their mistakes by not listening to their playerbase. 

The economic system is greedy, the gameplay is dated, this game is nothing more than Overwatch 1.5.

猫

从前，我养了一只猫，我有十块钱，会用八块钱给它买吃的，经常给它洗澡，它也很粘我。

后来，我带它出去玩，路人觉得它很可爱，他们给它喂猫粮，火腿肠，我很不开心，因为它是我的。我想把它抱回家，可是它挣脱我，冲着给它好吃的人喵喵，我抱了几次他都不跟我走，还挠伤了我，于是我转身就走了.....

后来，偶然在路上遇到了它，它身上脏兮兮的。路人们只会给它好吃的，陪它玩玩，却不会带它回家，给它洗澡。它看到我后就跟着我回家，我把它关在了门外，它在门外喵喵地叫着，叫的我很难受，
可是我不会再要它了
